title: MongoDB Schema Design
subject: MongoDB
theory: Schema design in MongoDB relies on the access patterns of your application. The key decision is always Embed (nesting data) vs Reference (linking data). Embed is better for read performance; Reference is better for data consistency and large datasets.

examples.explanation: Addresses are usually embedded because they belong to the user and are viewed with the user.

common_mistakes.correction: Don't nest too deep. Queries become complex and document size limits hit.

interview_questions.question: When should you use referencing over embedding?
interview_questions.answer: When the 'many' side is large (unbounded growth), frequently updated individually, or accessed typically without the parent.

exam_notes: Design for Usage (Read/Write patterns), not for SQL normalization.
summary: Good schema design is critical. In NoSQL, data structures are optimized for specific application queries.
